Celebrating my first publication

Iâ€™m excited to share that my very first research paper as a PhD student has been published online (and will soon be in print) in the journal Language, Cognition and Neuroscience ! This project was the first one I worked on at the start of my PhD, and I owe a huge thanks to my incredible supervisor, Wing-Yee, for her constant support and guidance. I couldnâ€™t have done it without her.

The paperâ€™s title is a bit technical: Revising Noun Predictions Based on English Measure Phrases: Evidence from Visual-World Eye-Tracking. But donâ€™t worry - Iâ€™ll explain it in simpler terms! You can click here to read the entire paper.

Whatâ€™s the paper about?

In everyday conversations, our brains are always trying to guess whatâ€™s coming next. For example, if I say I went to Starbucks and boughtâ€¦, you probably expect the next word to be coffee because thatâ€™s something youâ€™d typically buy at Starbucks. But what if I then say â€¦ a piece of ? Your brain would quickly revise its guess from coffee to something like cake instead.

Our study looks at how fast the brain can change these predictions when new information comes in. To do this, we used a method called visual-world eye-tracking. This technique measures where people are looking on a screen while they listen to sentences. By seeing which objects they look at, we can tell what theyâ€™re predicting.

For example, in our experiment, participants saw pictures of different objects on a screen: a cup of coffee, a piece of cake, and two unrelated things like a chair and a bird. We tracked where they were looking as they heard the sentence, I went to Starbucks and boughtâ€¦ At this point, most people looked at the picture of coffee, showing they expected coffee to be mentioned. But when the sentence continued with â€¦a piece ofâ€¦, they quickly shifted their gaze to the cake, revising their original guess. This shows how fast people can adjust their predictions when the new information doesnâ€™t match what they first expected.

Whatâ€™s unique about this study?

My supervisor and one of her previous students did a similar study with Mandarin Chinese. In Chinese, thereâ€™s something called classifiers that come between a number and a noun (like saying ä¸€æœµèŠ± <one CLduo flower> or ä¸¤æœ¬ä¹¦ <two CLben books>, where CL stands for classifier). They found that Mandarin speakers could use these classifiers to quickly adjust their predictions.

English doesnâ€™t have classifers but has a similar structure called measure phrases - phrases like a piece of, a glass of etc. Unlike classifiers in Chinese, measure phrases in English are optional. For instance, you can say three apples in English, but in Chinese, youâ€™d have to say ä¸‰é¢—è‹¹æœ (three CLke apples).

Our study compared how quickly people revise their predictions in English and Chinese when they hear these structures. We found no significant difference in how fast listeners in both languages make these revisions. This suggests that itâ€™s not about whether the structure is required, but how informative it is for helping listeners adjust their expectations.

Why is this important?

Being able to adjust predictions based on what we hear helps us understand language quickly and accurately. Our study provides new evidence showing just how fast and flexible this process can be!
